qas.question: What group of scientists study tectonics?
Which science is concerned with the study of the dynamics of ice?
Who is interested in the effects of harsh environment on humans?
What kind of observations use  the high elevations and thin atmosphere for viewing space?
Where is the largest neutrino telescope on Earth?

plausible_answers.text: celestial dome and cosmic microwave background radiation

qas.question: What do astrophysicists at the Scott-Aumundsen South Pole Station study?

plausible_answers.text: the largest neutrino telescope in the world

qas.question: What was built 2 mi below the Amundsen-Scott station?
Why are astronomical observations better made from most surface locations?

plausible_answers.text: the shield and the detection medium

qas.question: What does the 2 mile ice serve as for the telescope?

context: Researchers include biologists, geologists, oceanographers, physicists, astronomers, glaciologists, and meteorologists. <a0_0>Geologists<a0_0/> tend to study plate tectonics, meteorites from outer space, and resources from the breakup of the supercontinent Gondwana. <a1_0>Glaciologists<a1_0/> in Antarctica are concerned with the study of the history and dynamics of floating ice, seasonal snow, glaciers, and ice sheets. <a2_0>Biologists<a2_0/>, in addition to examining the wildlife, are interested in how harsh temperatures and the presence of people affect adaptation and survival strategies in a wide variety of organisms. Medical physicians have made discoveries concerning the spreading of viruses and the body's response to extreme seasonal temperatures. Astrophysicists at Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station study the <b5_0>celestial dome and cosmic microwave background radiation<b5_0/>. Many <a3_0>astronomical<a3_0/> observations are better made from the interior of Antarctica than from most surface locations <b7_0>because of the high elevation<b7_0/>, which results in a thin atmosphere; low temperature, which minimizes the amount of water vapour in the atmosphere; and absence of light pollution, thus allowing for a view of space clearer than anywhere else on Earth. Antarctic ice serves as both <b8_0>the shield and the detection medium<b8_0/> for <b6_0>the largest neutrino telescope in the world<b6_0/>, built 2 km (1.2 mi) below <a4_0>Amundsen–Scott station.
